value: File:Bundesarchiv N 1572 Bild-1925-051, Polarfahrt Dampfer "München", Hafen von Möller-Bay.jpg
Photo of Novaya Zemlya from a 1925 German expedition

. Its two major islands, called simply Severny (northern) and Yuzhny (southern), are vast.

As a mountainous archipelago in the Arctic Ocean, Novaya Zemlya is a remote and inhospitable place with very harsh weather. Due to its strategic position, it also has a history of use by the Russian (and Soviet) military, including being the site of the 1961 detonation of the
, which resulted in the most powerful nuclear blast ever produced by humankind.

value: File:Bundesarchiv N 1572 Bild-1925-052, Polarfahrt Dampfer "München", Ausbooten im Möllerhafen.jpg
Another photo of Novaya Zemlya from the 1925 German expedition

There are two weekly flights between

and Belushya Guba, the capital of Novaya Zemlya District. However, as there is restricted access to Novaya Zemlya, special permission from the Russian government (and perhaps the military itself) would be needed to visit.

value: A winter's night view of Rogachevo, Novaya Zemlya, in the 1990s

Beautiful scenery, wildlife such as polar bears.
